#Text=Gregory IV of Athens

#Text=Gregory IV , ( Greek : Γρηγόριος Αργυροκαστρίτης , Albanian : Grigor Gjirokastriti ; [ 1 ] died 1828 ) was a Greek [ 2 ] or Albanian scholar and cleric who became Metropolitan of Athens [ 1 ] in 1827 – 1828 . [ 1 ] [ 3 ] [ 4 ]
#Text=Title page of the New Testament in Greek and Albanian
#Text=Gregory was born in Gjirokastër ( Aryrokastro ) in the mid to late-18th century .
#Text=In ca.1784 he was a teacher in the New Academy , a famous educational institution in Moscopole , a leading center of Greek culture at the time . [ 5 ]
#Text=In 1799 he was appointed Bishop of Paramythia but remained in this position for only a few months .
#Text=In 1799 , while Patriarch of Constantinople was Gregory V , he was appointed Archbishop of Euboea , also called " Bishop of Evripos " .
#Text=In the summer of 1821 , when the Greek War of Independence spread to Euboea , the Turks put him under detention until January 1823 .
#Text=When freed , he immediately put himself at the disposition of the Greek Revolutionary Government .

#Text=In his letter to the High Parliament he thanks God for saving him from the hands of the " tyrants of the Nation " , expresses his will to " do his best effort for everything for the benefit of Greece and especially for the people of this island ( Euboea ) " and requests the Parliament to use him " for everything that may be beneficial to the Homeland " . [ 2 ] [ 6 ]

column1: #Text=It seems though , that before his detention Gregory had already been involved in the Revolution , because a good number of Epirots , and indeed many from Argyrokastro , had been fighting in Euboea .
#Text=It is assumed by the historians that this is the reason that the Turks had arrested him .
#Text=Gregory kept on informing the central government on the situation in Euboea , but the government did not use him for the Revolution .

#Text=By July 1823 the failure of Revolution in Euboea as well as the usurpation of his position by Bishop Neophytos of North Euboea , forced Gregory , among many others , to flee to Corfu retaining his title .
#Text=In Corfu he translated the New Testament from ancient Greek to Albanian along with Vangjel Meksi . [ 4 ]
#Text=This work was partially published in Corfu in 1824 and fully in 1827 . [ 7 ]
#Text=It contains both the Greek and the Albanian text , the latter printed in Greek letters , too . [ 8 ] [ 9 ]

#Text=Gregory divided the originally one volume edition of 839 pages into two volumes , considering it a more suitable solution because " Albanians kept the holy scriptures close to their chest " . [ 10 ]

#Text=it For this work one of his biographers Kourilas considers Gregory as " the founder of the Albanian philology " adding that " ... albanologists use this translation as basic text but they only mention his ( Gregory 's ) name ... but nothing about his home country and life " ( Kourilas , p.349 ) .
#Text=In 1827 he returned to Euboea and on 16 September he was appointed Metropolitan of Athens and remained so until his death , in March 1828 .
#Text=He was buried in Chalkis , Euboea , in accordance to his will . [ 11 ]
